name: Apotek Kitchen + Bar - Historic Pharmacy Building Restaurant
description: Apotek Kitchen + Bar occupies one of Reykjavík's most historically significant buildings—one of Iceland's first large concrete structures, designed by state architect Guðjón Samúelsson (1887-1950), who also created Hallgrímskirkja church and numerous other iconic Icelandic buildings that define the nation's architectural heritage. Located at Austurstræti 16 in the heart of downtown Reykjavík, the building functioned as Reykjavíkurapotek (the Reykjavík Pharmacy) from 1930 to 1999, earning its enduring nickname "Apotekið" that persists decades after the last prescription was filled. The restaurant's name and cocktail bar concept playfully references this pharmaceutical heritage—award-winning "pharmacists" (bartenders) mix artisan cocktails categorized as painkillers, stimulants, tranquilizers, and even placebos, creating whimsical connection between medicinal remedies and alcoholic libations while showcasing serious mixology skills that have earned recognition in Iceland's competitive cocktail scene. The building's architectural pedigree reflects the modernist concrete construction that represented progress and permanence when erected in 1930—at a time when most Icelandic buildings still used turf, stone, or imported timber, this imposing concrete structure symbolized Reykjavík's transition from fishing village to modern capital. Today's restaurant interior honors this heritage while creating contemporary dining atmosphere that balances historical gravitas with lively energy.
